title: Chilaquiles Rojos de Abuela Sofia
description: Ay, mijo/mija, prepare yourself for a taste of home! These Chilaquiles Rojos are just like the ones I used to make, full of rich tomato and chile flavor, with those perfectly crisp tortillas that soften just a bit in the sauce. It’s a hearty dish, perfect for breakfast, lunch, or even a light dinner. We make it with love, and you'll taste it in every bite. Don't be shy with the toppings, eh?

steps.instruction: First, let's get those chiles ready, mi amor. Carefully remove the stems and seeds from the guajillo and chile de árbol. If you like a little extra kick, you can leave a few seeds in the chile de árbol, but don't overdo it!

Now, for our beautiful sauce! In a medium saucepan, combine the cleaned chiles, roma tomatoes (halved), half of the white onion (roughly chopped), and the garlic cloves. Cover them with about 3 cups of water – just enough to submerge everything. Bring this to a gentle boil over medium-high heat, then reduce to medium-low and let it simmer for about 10 minutes, until the tomatoes are soft and the chiles are rehydrated and plump.

Once cooked, let the mixture cool for a moment. Then, carefully transfer it to your blender with about 1.5 cups of the cooking water, the chicken bouillon, kosher salt, black pepper, and dried oregano. Blend until it's wonderfully smooth. For a truly silky sauce, pass it through a fine-mesh strainer into a clean bowl, pressing down on the solids to extract all the flavor. You can discard the leftover pulp. If the sauce is too thick, add a little more of the reserved cooking water; if it's too thin, we'll simmer it down later.

In a large, deep skillet, add about 1 tablespoon of the vegetable oil and heat it over medium heat. Pour in your blended sauce (be careful, it might sizzle!). Bring it to a gentle simmer and let it cook for about 5 to 7 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the sauce darkens slightly and thickens a bit. Taste it, and adjust the salt if it needs a little more love.

While our sauce is simmering, let's prepare the tortillas. If you're using fresh corn tortillas, cut them into sturdy triangles. Heat the remaining vegetable oil (about 1.75 cups) in a separate large pan over medium-high heat. Fry the tortilla pieces in batches until they are golden and crispy, about 2-3 minutes per batch. You want them crunchy, but not burnt! Transfer the fried chips to a paper towel-lined plate to drain any excess oil. If you wish to add eggs, now is a good time to fry them to your liking, perhaps a sunny-side up or scrambled, as some like.

Now for the magic, mijo! Add the crispy tortilla chips directly into the simmering red sauce in the skillet. Gently fold them with a spatula until all the chips are beautifully coated. Let them cook together for just 1 to 2 minutes. We want them warm and coated, not soggy, so don't leave them too long! Remove from heat immediately.

Serve your Chilaquiles Rojos right away, while they are still warm and inviting. Divide them among plates. Drizzle generously with Mexican crema, crumble fresh queso fresco over the top, add slices of avocado, a sprinkle of fresh cilantro, and a little bit of the remaining diced white onion for garnish. If you made eggs, place one on top of each serving. Ay, qué rico! Enjoy with a warm hug from Abuela.

title: Sopa de Fideo de Abuela Sofia
description: Ah, mi'jos, this Sopa de Fideo is a warm hug in a bowl, just like my mother taught me. Simple, comforting, and full of that true casero flavor. Perfect for any day when you need a little cariño.

steps.instruction: First, mi'jos, we prepare our beautiful sauce. Roughly chop your Roma tomatoes, a quarter of the white onion, and the garlic clove. Place them in a blender with half a cup of water and blend until smooth. This is the heart of our sopa!

Next, in a medium pot or a deep skillet, heat the vegetable oil over medium heat. Add the fideo noodles and stir constantly until they turn a lovely golden brown. This gives them a beautiful nutty flavor. Be careful not to burn them, eh?

Once the fideo is golden, carefully pour in your blended tomato sauce. It will sizzle, so be a little careful! Stir it all together and let it cook for about 2-3 minutes, allowing the flavors to meld and the sauce to thicken just a little.

Now, add the four cups of vegetable broth to the pot. Bring the soup to a gentle boil, then reduce the heat to low, cover, and let it simmer. Cook until the fideo noodles are tender, usually around 10-12 minutes. Check a noodle to see if it's just right.

Finally, taste your Sopa de Fideo. Add salt and black pepper to your liking. Remember, the broth already has some seasoning, so add little by little. Serve it warm with a sprinkle of cilantro, a squeeze of lime, or a dollop of crema, if you wish. ¡Buen provecho!

title: Esquites de Abuela Sofia (Mexican Street Corn Salad)
description: ¡Ay, mi'jos! Let Abuela Sofia share a secret with you. Esquites, or as some call it, 'corn in a cup,' is a true taste of Mexico. It's like our famous elotes, but off the cob, so it's easier to enjoy with a spoon! This recipe brings together the best flavors and textures – sweet corn, smoky char, creamy sauce, and a little kick of chile. Perfect for any gathering, or just a cozy evening at home. Remember, the secret is always cooking with amor!

steps.instruction: First, gather all your beautiful ingredients. Finely chop the white onion, mince the garlic cloves, and seed and finely chop the jalapeño. If using fresh corn on the cob, carefully remove the kernels.

In a large skillet or wok, melt the butter over medium-high heat. Add the chopped onion, minced garlic, and jalapeño. Sauté until the onion becomes soft and translucent, about 3 to 4 minutes. The aroma will fill your kitchen, just like mine!

Add the fresh corn kernels to the skillet. Stir well to coat them with the butter and aromatics. Cook for about 2 minutes without moving, allowing some kernels to develop a nice, smoky char. Then, add the water, salt, and black pepper. Stir, cover, and let the corn simmer for 5 to 7 minutes, or until the kernels are tender and slightly plump. Remove from heat.

While the corn is cooking, prepare our creamy dressing. In a medium bowl, combine the mayonnaise, Mexican crema (or sour cream), the juice from half of the lime, and half a teaspoon of chili powder. Mix until everything is smooth and well combined.

Pour the warm corn mixture into a large serving bowl. Add the crumbled Cotija cheese, the chopped fresh cilantro, and the creamy dressing. Toss gently until all the corn kernels are beautifully coated.
Serve your esquites immediately in individual cups, just like they do in Mexico! Garnish with a sprinkle of extra chili powder and a lime wedge for squeezing. ¡Buen provecho!

title: Abuela Sofia's Pozole Rojo Tradicional
description: Ah, mi corazón, this is a recipe filled with tradition and love, just like my mama used to make. Pozole Rojo, a hearty Mexican soup with tender pork and hominy, all swimming in a rich, spicy red chili broth. It's an all-day project, sí, but the warmth and flavor that fills your home, and the smiles around your table, are worth every moment. This is a dish to share with family, a true taste of Mexico.

steps.instruction: First, we prepare our beautiful chiles. Gently remove the stems and all the seeds from both the Guajillo and Ancho chiles. Heat a dry comal or cast-iron pan over medium-high heat and toast the chiles for just a minute or two, until they become fragrant and slightly pliable. Be careful, mijo, don't let them burn! Then, place the toasted chiles in a medium pot, cover them with 3 cups of hot water, and let them soak for about 20-30 minutes until they are soft.

While the chiles are soaking, let's get our pork ready. Cut the pork shoulder into generous 1 to 1.5-inch cubes. Pat them dry with a clean cloth and season them generously with 1 tablespoon of salt. In your largest stockpot, heat the olive oil over medium-high heat. Brown the pork cubes in batches, making sure not to crowd the pot, until they are golden on all sides. This gives our pozole a deeper sabor. Remove the browned pork and set aside.

Now, add the browned pork back to the large stockpot. Add 5 quarts of fresh water, 2 whole garlic cloves, 1 chopped yellow onion, 3 bay leaves, and 1 tablespoon of salt. Bring it to a boil, then reduce the heat to a gentle simmer, cover, and let it cook for a good 2 to 2.5 hours, or until the pork is so tender it falls apart easily. Skim any foam that rises to the top, mi amor.

Once the chiles are soft, it's time to make our rich red sauce. Carefully transfer the rehydrated chiles to a blender. Add 4 fresh garlic cloves, 1 teaspoon of salt, and about 2 cups of the chile soaking liquid. Blend on high until you have a smooth purée. Now, for the secret to a perfect broth: strain this chili sauce through a fine-mesh sieve into a clean bowl, pressing down on the solids with a spoon to extract all the precious liquid. Discard the remaining pulp.

When the pork is tender, carefully remove it from the pot and shred it into bite-sized pieces using two forks. Discard any bones or excess fat. Strain the pork broth through a fine-mesh sieve back into the stockpot, discarding the cooked onion, garlic, and bay leaves.

Return the shredded pork to the strained broth. Open your large can of hominy, drain and rinse it well under cold water, then add it to the pot. Pour in your beautiful strained red chili sauce. Add the ground cumin and the Mexican oregano, crushing the oregano between your palms to release its aroma. Add another tablespoon of salt. Stir everything together gently.

Bring the pozole back to a gentle simmer, partially covered, for at least 60-90 minutes. This allows all the flavors to truly meld and deepen, making a magical broth. Taste and adjust the salt as needed; pozole often needs more than you think! If the broth becomes too thick, you can add a little more water.

While the pozole simmers, prepare your garnishes. Finely slice the green cabbage. Thinly slice the radishes. Finely chop the white onion and the fresh cilantro. Quarter your limes. And, if you like, dice your avocados. Arrange all these colorful toppings in separate bowls on the table.

When the pozole is ready, ladle generous portions into large soup bowls, making sure each bowl has plenty of tender pork, hominy, and rich broth. Let everyone choose their own garnishes – the more the merrier! Serve with crispy tostada shells on the side for dipping. ¡Buen provecho, mi familia!
